altNameGrp.name: Kyishö Zhabdrung Machen

person.note: Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131 assumes "ma chen" here (106v4) means "cook," translating this as "the zhabs-drung and the cook of skyid shod" (DMD 1/21/2009). "Ma chen" appears to be an honorific that is sometimes appended to high lama's names (bjd 2009-04-10).

Does he have another name? Jamyang Tulku is mentioned a number of times in the text. Is he the son of khal kha thu shi ye thu rgyal po (154r1)? (DMD 1/19/2009)
All versions of the text (114r2; 230.3) have "rgyal khang rtse"; it appears a number of times in the text

spus srang is probably a place (the madman of Pusang), but I cannot find any reference to it. (bjd 2009-04-01)

altNameGrp.name: Trülpé Chökyong Chenpo
sprul pa'i chos skyong chen po

deity.note: For more on this statue see: Franz-Karl Ehrhard, Die Statue und der Tempel des Arya Va-ti bzang-po: Ein Beitrag zur Geschichte und Geographie des Tibetischen Buddhismus (= Contributions to Tibetan Studies, 2). Wiesbaden 2004. and also Franz-Karl Ehrhard, “The Transmission of the Thig-le bcu-drug and the bKa’ gdams glegs bam ” in The Many Canons of Tibetan Buddhism (=Brill’s Tibetan Studies Library, 2:10)

Name variant: rang byung lnga ldan. This is the famous statue of Avalokiteshvara that Songtsen Gampo, his Chinese wife, and Nepalese wife, dissolved into at the end of their lives; see Bod rgya tshig mdzod chen mo, p.2650 and 2651

Keith Dowman in his "Power Places of Central Tibet", p.78, states that this deity, whose name variants are ma gcig dpal gyi lha mo and ma gcig dpal lha zhi ba’i nyams can, is a peaceful form of dpal ldan lha mo and she is peculiar to the brag yer pa area near Lhasa.

nameGrp.name: Drizé Gyelpo Zurpü Ngapa
dri za'i rgyal po zur phud lnga pa

deity.note: A google search suggests that this deity has close ties to Taranatha and the Jonang sect.
144v.1: rje btsun nA ro ta pa'i thugs dam rten rdo rje btsun mo'i sku brnyan ra tshag nas gdan drangs

nameGrp.name: Samyé Nöjin Chenpo
bsam yas gnod sbyin chen po
Chidak Nenpé Nachachen
'chi bdag mnan pa'i rna cha can

group.note: This family (?) is associated with Bhutan. Ardussi, “Formation of Bhutan”, p 30, note xxv mentions the lha pa family as “some-time followers of the Dalai Lama” who helped contribute to the dissent and infighting surrounding the creation of the state of Bhutan in the first half of the 17th century. The context in which it's mentioned in the text (111r1-111r2) supports this.

geogPlace.note: Check type: this may be a town
This is probably more of a village than a city
This is probably more of a village than a city
This is probably more of a village than a city
Should this be a village or a town as opposed to a region?
Should this be a village or a town as opposed to a region?
Should this be a village or a town as opposed to a region? Or is this a monastery?
Should this be a village or a town as opposed to a region?
It is my guess that this refers to a region; the Dalai Lama travels to Nakartse by way of "'om thang" (112r1; dmd 1/14/09)
Is gong dkar synonomous with gong ri dkar po (112r2)? Or is gong ri dkar po just the name of a monastery within gong dkar? (DMD 1/14/2009)

I assume this is a park/picnic ground in Lhasa (113r3; DMD 1/19/2009). The Dalai Lama is mentioned to have spent time there in 1640 during a festival time and staying in a tent (Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 126). Dowman, "Power Places of Central Tibet," pp 49-50, mentions a brag lha klu phug, a cave near Chakpori.

149r6: "lho brag do bo rdzong (G035) du dga' ldan don gnyis gling btsugs pa." I take this to mean that Dowo Dzong is a district in Lhodrak. Are districts "estates" in terms of our categories? (bjd 2009-03-31)

nameGrp.name: Lhatse Ganden Choling
lha rtse dga' ldan chos gling
Dratsang Ganden Sangngak Yangtsé
grwa tshang dga' ldan gsang sngags yang rtse

structure.note: Sorenson and Hazod's "Rulers on the Celestial Plain," p.979, may lead to information on this place
Not sure if this is a monastery or geographic region

nameGrp.name: Döl Ganden Sungrap Ling
dol dga' ldan gsung rab gling

structure.note: Is this a part of Sera monastery?
I am assuming this refers to Sera monastery in general, and not a specific monastic college (DMD 1/12/09). Dowman, "Power Places of Central Tibet," p 63, confirms this.
Should we assume this is the same as Olga Dzong? If so, must collapse these two entries and fix any references below

altNameGrp.name: Nampar Gyalwé Pendé Lekshé Ling
rnam par rgyal ba'i phan bde legs bshad gling

structure.note: Could be TBRC G3084 or G2426. Probably the latter. DMD 1/12/09
Could be TBRC G391.

altNameGrp.name: Nartang Purba Dratsang
snar thang phur pa gra tshang

structure.note: On pp 95v1 and 111r4 there is mention of "snar thang phur pa ba", which implies that this phur pa grwa tshang is part of snar thang monastery (DMD 1/14/09).
This could be part of a larger monastery, but I cannot figure out which one that would be. Maybe klu sdings? (110v3-110v4; DMD 1/12/2009)
Listed as a college of ngor e waM chos ldan (TBRC G211); not sure if that's what this reference (110v4) is to (DMD 1/12/2009)
This is likely a college within a larger monastery (111r5; DMD 1/14/2009)
This monastery is mentioned by Dowman, "Power Places of Central Tibet," p 272. It is just south of Shalu. (DMD 1/14/2009)

nameGrp.name: Podrang Gongri Karpo
pho brang gong ri dkar po

structure.note: pho brang gong ri dkar po: mentioned 112r2: assuming this in in gongkar; not sure if this is synonomous with gong dkar dgon, or any other monastery
Mentioned 113r6

altNameGrp.name: Tanak Drölmawa Kuché Dratsang
rta nag sgrol ma ba sku mched gra tshang

structure.note: Not sure exactly what the name of the place is. The first reference is to "rta nag sgrol ma ba sku mched gra tshang gi gra pa brgyad bcu skor" (148r3) and then later to "rta nag sgrol ma nas sku mched" (bjd 2/10/2009).
Is this a monastery or a school? Is it the same as another sorik lapdra that seems to be in Zhigatse at other places in the text? (bjd 02-18-2009)
Cabezon's project has some info on early Sera colleges: http://www.thlib.org/places/monasteries/sera/.
Cabezon's project has some info on early Sera colleges: http://www.thlib.org/places/monasteries/sera/.

nameGrp.name: Rangjön Pakpa Jikten Wangchukgi Tsuklak Khang
rang byon 'phags pa 'jig rten dbang phyug gi gtsug lag khang

structure.note: Maybe a temple in the Potala? (bjd 2009-04-01)

nameGrp.name: Drakhang Sangngak Gatsel Bukgi Tsangkhang
gra khang gsang sngags dga' tshal sbug gi gtsang khang

structure.note: Mentioned at 149v2, assuming that this is a temple in the Potala. (bjd 2009-04-07)
Mentioned at 149v2, assuming that this is a temple in the Potala. (bjd 2009-04-07)

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama receives extensive offerings from a group of visitors ('grul pa mangs)
An envoy (mi sna) of Khalkha Dorjé Gyelpo brings a gift and a request that the Dalai Lama go to Mongolia (sog yul)
The Dalai Lama gives the name "Ngawang Jamyang Lhündrup" to the 4th Tongkor (stong ‘khor) incarnation

event.note: The Great Prayer Festival over, the Dalai Lama goes to Drepung monastery

socialEvent.note: The Lady (dpon mo) of Orö Yönru Mergen Daichin has a statue made for his spiritual benefit; the Dalai Lama consecrates it

The Tibetan reads: o rod g.yon ru mergan da'i chin gyi [105v6] dge rtsar dpon mos de bzhin gshegs pa'i dngul sku bsrun par gzungs bzhugs... I am assuming that when it says dpon mo, it necessarily means the wife of o rod g.yon ru mergan da'i chin. Otherwise it would just be some dpon mo and we would have no way of identifying her whatsoever. At 106r2 there is mention of g.yon ru'i dpon mo, which confirms this reading
Nomön Khan gives raw materials to make a silver statue in memory of Zhabdrung Jampa; the Dalai Lama facilitates its construction
The Dalai Lama interacts with the monks of Pendé Lekshé Ling
The Dalai Lama gives teachings and gifts to Sechen Nomön Khan, Yönru’s Lady and other travelers
The Dalai Lama makes offerings to the tutelary deities and dharma protectors (yi dam chos srung rnams) in thanks for Gushri Khan's success in bringing all of Tibet under his control

Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, reads this different, saying that it is the monks of the Lhasa monasteries who are doing this. This means taking the agent from after the "shing" that separates/connects this action from the next one. I read it differently, assuming that the unstated agent of the first action is the Dalai Lama himself, and that the second action is completely separate. (DMD 1/21/2009)

event.note: There is celebration in Drepung, Sera, Lhasa and so on that Gushri Khan had brought all the Tibetan areas under his control (mnga' 'og tu bod shing sgo can rnams chud pa)
Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, also describes these events, translating this exact passage.

socialEvent.note: Zur Künkyen Chenpo gives the Dalai Lama a teaching, to help him endure his associations with so many whose vows had been broken during the fighting
Karmay, “Secret Visions of the 5th DL” p 29 says Zur gives him amulets and empowered water here; I do not think the Tibetan says as much (DMD 1/21/2009)

event.note: The Dalai Lama leaves Drepung on the 11th day of the 3rd month
Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, says the 11th day of the third months is 9 April 1942.
Dalai Lama passes through Tölung
Dalai Lama arrives at Uyuk Lingkar

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama is greeted in Tobgyel by Gushri Lama, the "zhelngo" (Sönam Chöpel), Garu Kachu, Erteni Daichin, Kyishö Zhabdrung Machen, monks and laypeople
Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, reads this differently. Ahmad says that all these people are coming out to meet Gushri Khan, not the Dalai Lama.

Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, reads "ma chen" as "cook." Although in colloquial Tibetan "ma chen" certainly does mean cook, it seems more likely to me that here it would refer to a high-ranking female (?) or some other rank (DMD 1/21/2009)
Karmay, "Secret Visions of the 5th Dalai Lama," p 9, also describes thes events.
The Gyelpo (Gushri Khan?) gives the Dalai Lama various material gifts and offers him Tibet itself, with all 13 divisions, which had in the past passed from Neudong to the Rinpungpas.

I assume the rgyal po mentioned here is Gushri Khan. Could it be the defeated Tsangpa "king"? Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, translates this passage, but just says "the king" without elaborating on who that would be. (DMD 1/21/2009)

Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, says that Tibet itself is given to the Dalai Lama here. It first I read it differently, thinking it was gifts from all over Tibet that were given to him. But because of the line about it having passed from Neudong to the Rinpungpa, he must be talking about Tibet itself (DMD 1/21/2009)
Karmay, "Secret Visions of the 5th Dalai Lama," p 9, also describes thes events.
Tsedong Zhabdrung Rinpoché offers tea to the Dalai Lama (ja 'dren)
Dalai Lama has correspondence with Sakya Rabjampa and Tazhing Chöjé
The Dalai Lama is greeted by the monks of Serdokchen
Dalai Lama has a conversation with Kenpo Adü
Dalai Lama has an encounter with Ken Chakdampa

participantPersonUnnamed.note: This is the treasurer/secretary (phyag mdzod) of the bla brang

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama is greeted by Nenying Zhabdrung, the lobpön of Tashi Lhünpo, the treasurer/secretary (phyag mdzod), Lhündrup Lingpa, and other Tibetans; and Mongols, including Jinong, Sechen Hung Taiji, and about 600 horsemen

event.note: On the 25th day of the 3rd month, the Dalai Lama arrives at Tashi Lhünpo, accompanied by a procession of monks
Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131, says the 25th day of the third months is 23 April 1942

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama, at Tashi Lhünpo, meets with the Penchen Lama
The Dalai Lama helps the people in the monastery (gling gseb tu) who had been reduced to destitution, as requested by Kangmarwa, former abbot of Tsetsok
The Dalai Lama is receiving an endless stream of visitors - Tsangpas and Mongolians, monks and laypeople - from morning until night
Dalai Lama meets with Pandita Möndro Chenmo

The Dalai Lama goes before an assembly of innumerable Tibetans and Mongolians. It is proclaimed that the 13 myriarchies of Tibet, including Zhikatsé, are offered to the Dalai Lama (gzhis ka bsam grub rtses thog drangs bod khri skor bcu gsum yongs su rdzogs pa 'bul ba yin zhes dril bsgrags). He is also given magnificent gifts including relics of the Buddha that were given to Pakpa by Khubilai Khan centuries earlier

It is very unclear what is going on here in the text (107v3-107v6). There is more detail that I can't make out, but this is basically what's going on. See "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131 for a translation of this passageDMD 1/13/09

The location for this could be "Zhikatse", following Ahmad ("Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," p 131) who reads "rtser" as shorthand for "zhikatse". I would rather take it to mean "fortress." This reading is suggested by Karmay, "Secret Visions of the 5th DL", p 9, when he says this ceremony takes place at "khams gsum zil gnon" (the Karmapa monastery/fortress above Tashilhunpo (?)). (DMD 1/21/2009)
There is a list of the many worship items offered by the Dalai Lama to Nampar Gyalwé Pendé Lekshé Ling over the next 18 years
The Dalai Lama interacts with Gyari Zhabdrung Lozang Tutob Chögyel
This might be prayers offered after Gyari Zhabdrung Lozang Tutob Chögyel's death (110r2); it's unclear what is meant by gshegs
The Dalai Lama discusses with Gushri Khan (rgyal po) and the Depa regarding what to do about the other sects, using Pakpa as an example. There is some disagreement.
The Dalai Lama gives a teaching to the entire monastic assemby of Tashi Lhünpo
Dalai Lama interacts with Penchen Chökyi Gyelpo in the context of consecrating new stupas
With Penchen Rinpoché acting as kenpo and the Dalai Lama as löbpön, full ordination is given to a group of novices, including Gushri Lama

event.note: The Dalai Lama leaves Tashi Lhünpo to begin his trip back to Lhasa, via the southern route

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama is invited to Zhalu Ritil by Rinchen Sönam Chokdrup, the umdzé of Zhalu Ribuk. The Dalai Lama gives a teaching to the monks of the monastery
The Dalai Lama is greeted by the monks of the Purba monastic college (phur pa grwa tshang) and the Mani practice center (ma Ni sgrub sde)

event.note: The Dalai Lama stays for two days at Luding

I am assuming Luding (klu sdings) is a monastery, but this could be wrong. It is listed as a college within ngor e waM chos ldan monastery, but I'm not sure where that is and if this could be it, geographically speaking. (DMD 1/12/2009)

socialEvent.note: A member of the Lhapa family arrives to discuss with the Dalai Lama, Gushri Khan and the depa (mchod yon) military action in Bhutan
Dalai Lama interacts with Drodönling, Tarpa and the Purpa monastic college of Nartang, regarding their loyalties and estates
The Dalai Lama speaks with Kalapa, who relieves some of his doubts

I am not entirely sure who this "ka lA pa" is and whether it's a proper name of an individual. "ka lA pa" can refer to the name of a city in Shambhala, or an Indian grammatical treatise (kalapavyakarana). It could be that the Dalai Lama asks questions regarding the kalApa, but then no interlocutor would be supplied by the text (111r6; DMD 1/14/2009)

event.note: The Dalai Lama arrives in Gyelkartsé, met with great fanfare
The Dalai Lama visits the Pelkor Chödé

socialEvent.note: The 7 Geluk monastic colleges at the Pelkor Chödé throw a reception for the Dalai Lama

event.note: The Dalai Lama passes through Omtang on his way to Nakartsé
The Dalai Lama arrives at Nakartsé

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama is greeted at Nakartsé by, and exchanges gifts with, Zhangpo Tripön and his brother (sku mched gnyis)
The Dalai Lama has a discussion with the zhabdrung (of Nakartsé) about the extent of the latter's learning
There is a large procession welcoming the Dalai Lama to Podrang Gongri Karpo
I'm assuming pho brang gong ri dkar po is in the geoplace gong dkar, but the two aren't synonomous (DMD 1/14/2009)
Dharmalord caretaker Geteng Lama Jampa Künga Jungné and other caretakers (dkon gnyer) put on a ritual dance (’cham) performance for the Dalai Lama
The Dalai Lama speaks at length with Yongzin Tülku (reincarnation of Lama Lhatsewa)

In conversation, the Depa suggests to the Dalai Lama that he move his primary residence to Lhasa. The Dalai Lama responds negatively, saying that he does not want to get any more caught up in worldly affairs.
This passage is translated by Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," pp 139-140.
The Dalai Lama is invited to Sangpu by Lingmé Zhabdrung; he is welcomed by the monastery's teachers

participantDeityUnnamed.note: It just says "chos skyong"; could be one or many

socialEvent.note: At Sangpu, the Dalai Lama makes offerings to statues of Drölma Tsögyelma, Ngok Lotsawa and the dharma protectors
DL is making an offering to the STATUE of rngog lo tsA ba. Do I treat him as a person (present or not present?) or as a deity? (DMD 1/19/2009)
The Dalai Lama has an exchange of offerings (gzhis len) with Lingmé (Zhabdrung)
The text just says he has gzhis len with glinh smad; I assume this means gling smad zhabs drung
The Dalai Lama makes offerings at a temple dedicated to local spirits temple

event.note: The Dalai Lama arrives at Drepung

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama is welcomed back to Drepung monastery by the monastic community ('dus tshogs)

event.note: Monks of Sera Tekchen Ling, Gyütö, Meru (rmi ru/rme ru) and other monasteries, along with singers, dancers and performers, set up camp in Lupuk Lingka and stay for 15 days

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama sends a letter to Jamyang Tülku
Made a new person entry for this Jamyang Tulku. If we later realize that this is synonomous with someone else, the entries should be collapsed. (DMD 1/22/2009)
Ganden Tri Rinpoché Jangrampa comes to the Dalai Lama, along with members of the Tsé and Shar monastic colleges

Ganden Tri Rinpoche comes along with "rtse shar gnyis”; I assume this means the monks (or representatives) of two monastic colleges at Ganden? But it is unclear which ones. If they can be identified, they should be added to the entry. (DMD 1/19/2009)
The Dalai Lama goes to visit the Jokang, and the people of Lhasa put on a dance performance
The Dalai Lama appoints Erteni Chöjé abbot of the Pelkor Chödé
dpal 'khor chos sde'i mkhan por er te ni chos rje bskos: is it implied that the DL is a part of this process, or does it happen without him? (DMD 1/19/2009)
Should add another structure ref, to show that the dalai Lama is still at the Jokang
The Dalai Lama has an exchange of worship materials with Drakna Chöjé
The grammar here is a mess; this is our best guess at what could be going on here (discussed in a meeting, 1/21/2009).

event.note: The Dalai Lama goes to Drepung
1642.08.28: The Dalai Lama gets over a serious illness that had been affecting him for two months
Karmay, “Secret Visions of the 5th DL” p 29-30 describes his sickness and the miraculous visions that occur when he gets better.

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama meets with many travelers, including including the Right Division commander of Khalkha, Erteni Hungtaiji, Tongkor Zhabdrung, and the tülku of Gyelkangtsé (rgyal khang rtse sprul sku)
"rgyal khang rtse", although at first looking suspicious, appears to be correct; it's attested to a number of times in the text (DMD 1/19/2009)

It is really unclear how all these names should be split up: is Erteni Hungtaiji the Right Division commander of Khalkha? Is the stong 'khor zhabs drung the rgyal khang rtse sprul sku? Elsewhere in the text (153v1) it's suggested that stong 'khor sprul sku is associated with the Right Division of the Khalkha.

Because of these difficulties, I have only included in this entry: the Dalai Lama, Erteni Hungtaiji, Tongkor Shabdrung, and the Gyelkangtse Tulku. If more information comes along and we figure out who these folks are, the entry can be fixed then.

event.note: There is an uprising led by Garpa Yapsé, a supporter of the Karmapa; Gushri Khan and Sönam Chöpel (rgyal po mchod yon) go by way of Medro to take care of it
There is a description of these events in Shakabpa, pp 111-112.

socialEvent.note: Northward travelers (byang ‘grul rnams) stopping over in Lhasa fete the Dalai Lama with offerings and invitations for about 10 days

event.note: There is a long description of the events surrounding the uprising, including military confrontations in Zhikatsé, Dzingchi and Kongpo; the safety of the Penchen Lama is a concern. A rebel emissary is captured and inside his charm box (ga’u) are found the rebel faction’s grand plans: kill Gushri Khan and Sönam Chöpel; imprison the Dalai Lama and Penchen Lama in Kongpo; and destroy the Geluk monasteries. As the fighting winds down, discussion again turns to how the different sects of Buddhism ought to be treated.
There is a description of these events in Shakabpa, pp 111-112.

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama gives teachings to travelers, including Erteni Hungtaiji
The Dalai Lama prepares rituals (chog bsgrigs) for Vishnu and Rahula

event.note: Gushri Khan and Sönam Chöpel (mchod yon) go to Kongpo with their army

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama has correspondence with the Depa (Sönam Chöpel) and Tardongné
The Dalai Lama composes a praise (sku bstod) and long-life supplication to Lingmé Zhabdrung Rinpoché
The Dalai Lama makes offerings to the dharma protectors in appreciation for the defeat of the Kongpo army
The Dalai Lama corresponds with the umdzé of Riwo Dechen, Lozang Tenpel, regarding the latter’s need for an upper robe
The Dalai Lama composes a text, fulfilling a need expressed by Tazhing Chöjé
The Dalai Lama interacts with Zur Jamyang Lama
The Dalai Lama exchanges letters with Erteni Hungtaiji
The Dalai Lama impresses on Gushri Khan (rgyal po) the perils of warlordship; Kunji Gyelmo agrees with him
The Dalai Lama gives an authorization (rjes gnang) to Kushri Khan (rgyal po) and (Erteni Hung) Taiji
I am assuming from context that this "tha'i ji" is Erteni Hung Taiji
The Dalai Lama exchanges texts with Shabdrung Nyingnying
Tertön Rikdzin Chenpo Yolmo Tulpé Ku comes from Dorjé Drak and performs miraculous revelations
The Dalai Lama meets Vishnu (khyab 'jug) and Mantra Protector (sngags srung) in a dream
Khalkha Erteni Hung Taiji and travelers ('grul pa) make extensive offerings to the Dalai Lama
The Dalai Lama writes a text for a silver mandala offered by (Erteni Hung) Taiji to the Jowo
The Dalai Lama writes a text derived from a teaching of Kachu Tenpa Dargyé
The Dalai Lama writes a text at the request of Erké Taiji
The Dalai Lama writes a devotional verse (gsol 'debs) in honor of Dorjéchang Peljor Lhündrup, and sends it to Pabongka
(Erteni Hung) Taiji, on behalf of the Khalkha people, invites the Dalai Lama to Mongolia (sog yul)
Dalai Lama gives parting gifts to travelers ('grul pa) lead by (Erteni Hung) Taiji
There is correspondence between the Dalai Lama and Taklung Zhabdrung
I am assuming this stag lung zhab drung to be stag lung zhabs drung ngag dbang bkra shis dpal grub kar dge

event.note: The Dalai Lama goes to Drepung

socialEvent.note: The depa and Gushri Khan (mchod yon) arrive at Drepung, where the Dalai Lama is staying
Assuming mchod yon refers to the sde pa (Sonam Chopel) and Gushri Khan

Meeting with the Pelden Sakyapa and the Neudong Gongma at the horse races; there is a question of who should pay respect to whom, and the Dalai Lama decides to be subservient, which pleases the others
Not sure who exactly dpal ldan sa skya pa or sne'u sdong gong ma are; made generic entries under these names; can clarify once we figure out specifically who they are
The Dalai Lama sends a text to Mergen Kachu Sherap Gyatso
The Dalai Lama receives teachings from Zur Kyabdak Chenpo
I'm assuming zur khyab bdag chen po is same as zur thams cad mkhyen pa

event.note: There is a fire at the lower part of the "palace" (pho brang) where the Dalai Lama is staying; it if weren't for the religious means used to turn it back, the entire "palace" would have burned
there's a fire "pho brang zhol la " : I am assuming this is at Drepung
Dalai Lama moves to Sera while they are doing construction at Drepung, repairing damage from the fire

socialEvent.note: The monastic college headed by Drakna Chöjé perform a ritual to subdue a demonic force
This might not actually count as an exchange, because the DL's involvement isn't stated, but I think it can be assumed that they're doing the rituals on his behalf, or something like that
Dalai Lama offers a thanksgiving (gtang rag), scarf and a composition to Chidak Nenpé Nachachen (Earringed Subduer of the Lord of Death)

Lingmé Zhabdrung Rinpoché comes from Sangpu. He and the Dalai Lama discuss the possibility of building something on Marpori, the abode of Avalokiteshvara, to help bind together Sera and Drepung and to help expiate the sins of the Depa and Gushri Khan.
Would like to add another structureRef here, for Drepung. This person came FROM Sangpu TO Drepung. Shouldn't both places be represented?
This passage is translated by Ahmad, "Sino-Tibetan Relations in the 17th Century," pp 139-140.
The Dalai Lama gives an empowerment to Gushri Khan (rgyal po) and the Depa

event.note: The repairs from the fire completed, the Dalai Lama returns to Drepung from Sera

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama composes a text for Gushri Khan (rgyal po)
The Dalai Lama exchanges letters with Zur Künkyen Chenpo regarding whether or not the Dalai Lama should go to Mongolia (sog yul)
I am assuming zur kun mkhyen chen po, zur thams cad mkhyen pa, and zur khyab bdag chen po are all the same person
There is a disturbance at the Dratsang Chökor Ling and the Dalai Lama tries to help resolve the situation
Could Dratsang Chökor Ling be a part of Sera monastery, or maybe Drepung? Here I have made it its own entity
The Dalai Lama consecrates a statue of the Gushri Lama, for which the Depa was responsible
Dalai Lama sends six men to Gongkar to learn cham (ritual dance)

Does this refer to a monastery in Gongkar, or Gongkar itself? Probably the former, but since I don't know exactly which monastery that would be, I'm just saying he sent them to gong dkar the place (DMD 1/14/2009)

It is unclear from the grammar whether they are going to STUDY or to TEACH cham and music - the verb used is "bslab." But we know from the Dalai Lama's visit in 1642 that Gongkar has great mastery in dance and music, so I think it safe to assume that these monks are going there to learn it. (DMD 1/22/2009)
The Dalai Lama composes a text for and exchanges art with Khalka Rabjampa Lozang Peljor and Rabjampa Ngawang Gelek
Dalai Kunchi Gyelmo is sick; the Dalai Lama does rituals to heal her
Gushri Khan (rgyal po) and his main queen (rgyal mo che ba) persistently invite 5th DL to Tsokha (mtsho kha)
The Dalai Lama consults Rikdzin Yolmowa about whether or not he should heed the king and queen's request to travel

Am not 100% positive who the other participant is here - either Zur Kunkyen or Rikdzin Yolmo Tulku (P107). The Tibetan reads: zur kun mkhyen brgyud rigs 'dzin yol mo ba. This implies that it's "Rikdzin Yolmowa, holder of the Zur's lineage", but this seems backwards. According to TBRC, Yolmo was a teacher of Zur, and not the other way around. But maybe they exchanged teachings with one another?
The Dalai Lama composes the Debter Chikyi Gyelmo (deb ther dpyid kyi rgyal mo) at the request of Gushri Khan (rgyal po)
The six whom the Dalai Lama had previously sent to study cham and music at Gongkar, along with Könnyer Pöngé Teng Lama, arrive (before the Dalai Lama)

event.note: Smallpox ('brum nag) spreads from Tsang to Ü

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama meets ('byor) a group of travelers, lead by Wensa Tulku and Torgö Daichin
Taklung Zhabdrung arrives and gives the Dalai Lama teachings

event.note: The Dalai Lama leaves for Olga ('ol dga') as a precaution because of the spread of smallpox
The Dalai Lama arrives in Medro Gungkar

socialEvent.note: Taklung Zhabdrung Machen invites the Dalai Lama to tea when he arrives in Medro Gungkar
The Dalai Lama meets with Uma Lotsawa; they exchange texts

event.note: The Dalai Lama stays two days at Dzingchi (monastery)
The Dalai Lama stays 10 days at Olga Dzong

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama travels to Chökorgyel (monastery) with the priest and patron (mchod yon)
Assuming mchod yon refers to the sde pa and Gushri Khan

event.note: Snowfall covers all of Tibet

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama arrives in Gyeltil and many monastics and laypeople of the Dak(po) region come to meet him

The Dalai Lama gives an explanation (mjal kha) to Gushri Khan (rgyal po) and some of his servants (rgyal dpon g.yog nyung bsdus) regarding some of the religious images (nang rten), including the thunderbolt dagger (gnam lcags ral gris).

The Dalai Lama gives blessings to protect people returning to Kyishö (skyid shod). The full Tibetan describing these people is as follows: skyid shod du log dgos shar bar bar chad mi 'jug pa'i gson bsngo zhu mi.

event.note: The Dalai Lama stays at Olgatsé
('ol dga' rtse; should we assume this is the same as Olga Dzong ('ol dga' rdzong) and collapse the two?

socialEvent.note: folio 127b: "annual gifts from the leaders of districts and estates were displayed", list of 31 (groups of?) leaders from specific places

event.note: Dalai Lama goes from Jokhang Temple to Drepung.

socialEvent.note: Are the last or last two participants involved or is it their reincarnations?
Gyariwa (rgya ri ba) and Khyishopa (skyid shod pa) seem to refer to the leaders of those areas in this event, but unclear. They are listed as unnamed participants in this event. bjd
The lamas referenced in this passage seem to be associated with three particular monasteries but hard to track down all three: bde chen chos 'khor/ drin las pa/ lcog grwa
P006 and P049 are being refered to in the text together as "smon 'gro paN chen yab sras"
There is a time reference here (zla smad), but I am not sure what month it refers to. Probably the end of the second month, since the third month starts shortly after.
Unnamed person: zur rtsa ba'i bla ma. Not sure if this is refering to a particular person, such as zur tham cad mkhyen pa.
Gushri Khan and Sonam Chopel are being refered to in the text as "mchod yon rnams"
This event concerns the place 'dam bsam grub sde chen.

Is the deity here a participant? bjd 2008-10-28. "sde pa 'dam bsam grub sde chen gyi mkhar las kyi zhal bkod la thegs [141v2] skabs ar po la brten pa'i bar chad mi 'byung ba'i dri za'i rgyal po zur phud lnga pa la 'phrin 'chol bkod pa'i snyan dar /"
P006 and P049 are being refered to in the text together as "sku mdun smon 'gro nas yab sras"
Interesting event concerning a disagreement about the summer retreat (dbyar gnas).
The dates for this event are inferred from its occurance during the annual Curd Feast (zho ston).
Gives the time as the fifteenth day, but does not give month. Probably 15th of the 6th month, since a mention of seventh month comes shortly after. bjd 2008-11-11
P002 and P043 are mentioned as "mchod yon."
Unnamed participant is "gong dkar dgon gnyer dpon pa."
The Depa makes instructions (zhal bkod mdzad) and they (including the Dalai Lama here) arrange a new shrine.

To those previous messangers (see event in previous year for names, here just referred to as gong gi gser yig pa rnams) the Dalai Lama give several empowerments and reading transmissions (rjes gnang, lung).
There is a fear of pox and fever in China. In response, the Dalai Lama sends Kachu Sherap Gyeltsen and his translator Hor Trashi.

event.note: The Dalai Lama relates some recent political and economic events. He ends by mentioning that he is writing the biographies of Gushri Khan and the Depa Sönam Rapten since they have done good work and there is no biography yet.

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama gives a series of empowerments and vows.

Unclear passage (bjd): dga' ldan pho brang shar gyi mkhar las lo sngon ma thog zo gnyis grub pa'i 'phros dang zhol du ar po tshugs song bar phur sgrub kyis mtshon pa'i sku rim khang zhig byung na zhus pas rkyen byas gnas rnying pa dang rdo rje [147v5] brag par rnying ma'i chos bshad pa la bsnyad pa'i sgyur sbyang mang du mdzad byung ba la lan 'bul ma nus par spam me bsdad / yun ring tsam rgyu mtshan cher ma zhus par thugs tshom shar ba'i dogs sel gyi mol mchid zhib tu mdzad byung ba'i 'phros shig la [147v6] dbang chos mang ba dgos pa yong na sde drug mkhan po kha rab pa lta bu yar klungs bkra shis rtser btang na gsung bar nga rje bsod nams rgya mtsho las mi lhag / dbon rin po che bod mkhar ba las mi zhan de rigs bar du brgyud na mtshan nyid dang ldan pa [148r1] yong ba dka' zhus par 'phral du gsal kha ma byung yang ston mjug thugs bad dangs pa'i phyag tu bkal song /
Dalai Lama gives reading transmissions and empowerments to Tatsak Jedrung, Nenying Zhapdrung, and about twenty other people.

Ne'udong Zhapdrung comes to receive getsül vows. The Dalai Lama gives him an ordination name and then bestows empowerments and transmissions on Ne'udong Zhapdrung, Nenying Tripa, and monks from a monastic college.

Unclear whether the following passage is linked to this one. It appears that the ruler of Taktse's relatives arranged the seating at the assembly. 148r.4: "stag rtse tha'i ji sku mched kyis rdzong gi sgyed bu kha dror tshoms chen du bzhugs gral bshams /" (bjd 02/10/2009)
Dalai Lama establishes a new torma offering liturgy and then makes extensive offerings and petitions to great and small protectors and their helpers.

A Gelukpa monastery was newly built in Shelkar, but an old Tsangpa lama (bla ma gtsang pa rgad bu zhig) took all the monks wages and there was no benfit to the monastery. Then the Dalai Lama appointed Kongpo Chapnak Rapjampa Sanggyé Penjor and now things are progressing.
The Gyelmo Chungwa is struck with a strong disease, so the Dalai Lama give her some instructions for the time of death.

A long list of offerings are made to the Jowo statue, the great lamas of Tibet, and 132 monasteries, chiefly Sera, Ganden, and Drepung. These are made in order to gain merit on behalf of the dying Gyelmo Chungma. Finally, a silver stupa is constructed (presumably for her remains).
Unclear who is actually making the donations. I have assumed that the Dalai Lama is organizing all of it. (bjd 02/10/2009)

event.note: In the previous earth-snake [year], there was a prophesy by Dorjé Chang Phabong Khapa which came about at that time. For five days continuously the sun was obscured by a fog so that it looked like a copper plate.

socialEvent.note: Tendzin Chögyel's (Gushri Khan) body has some kind of affliction (dog cher yod pa) which seemed to be repelled by a healing ritual.
Odd passage: "bstan 'dzin chos rgyal la sku dog cher yod pa rim gros bzlog par snang /" (bjd 02/10/2009)

The Dalai Lama gives empowerments and transmissions (rjes gnang, chos spyod, lung) to Nenying Zhapdrung, monks and instructors from Sera Jé and Sera Mé, religious practitioners from Tanak Drölma, and residents of a medical school (gso rig slob gra) and of Meru monastery.
The Dalai Lama gives empowerments (rjes gnang) to Nenying Zhapdrung [and?] a small gathering of instructors (dpon slob nyung bsdus).
Monks of a monastic college arrange a ceremony for the Dalai Lama to remain for a long time.
The Dalai Lama accomplishes empowerments, transmissions, and vows for people including Lama Drölmané, Ngakchang Döndrup Trashi, the Chöpön, and the Umdzé (mchod dpon dbu mdzad).

The Dalai Lama goes to Drepung and the assembly which gathered for the arrival performs a prayer of true words so that he will stay a long time, and the Chögyel Chenpo (Nechung Oracle) also comes having entered his medium.

event.note: The Dalai Lama arrives at the Potala.

socialEvent.note: The whole assembly of monks from Sera Tekchen Ling arranged for a long life ceremony in the assembly hall of the Potala.
The Dalai Lama sends Ngawang Gyatso to be the lama at the [newly] established monastery of Ganden Dönnyi Ling in Lhodrak.
Dalai Lama gives full ordination to some of those acting [as] lamas of of Upper Sera monastic college (se ra stod pa'i bla ma byed mi), those of Dromteng college ('brom steng pa can).
Passage is a little confusing as to how these lamas are related to these two colleges. (bjd 2009-04-07)
For info on early Sera colleges see Cabezon's Sera Monastery Project on THL website.
Messengers arrive with the completed blocks for several books of royal annals which the Depa Lha Gyariwa and his ministers had managed.

In the fifth month they [perform] the thread-cross ritual offering of Sisum Dakmo. The Dalai Lama summons some skilled artisans who are led by Epa Trüku Hordar and Bakdro. In the inner shrine room of the Sangngak Gatsel assembly hall and in the female protector hall/shrine they erect statues for which the Dalai Lama offers dharanis from the tantras to place inside. The Dalai Lama he performes a brief consecration of the images.
At the urging of the Madman (smyon pa) of Püsang, the Dalai Lama arranges a series of paintings of the Buddha'a previous lives ('khrungs rabs).
The Dalai Lama composes works for Könchok Lodrö, Taktsé Teji Tsogyé Dorjé, and the [monks?] who perform rituals on the tenth day in Lhasa (lha sa'i tshes bcu pa rnams).

The Dalai Lama performs a about thirty initiations, permissions, and reading transmissions (dbang, rjes gnang, lung) for Demo Trülku before the latter departs for Barkham. He also gives teachings to Drakna Chöjé Drupchen Bakdro, the Chöpön, and the Umdzé.

event.note: The Dalai Lama composes a manual (yig cha) on offering dharanis.

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama completes the remainder of the Kadam Chöjung for Chöjé Draknawa and others who requested it (chos zhu gzhi ba rnams?).
The Dalai Lama gives teachings to Chöjé Pöndarwa, Drupchen Bakdro Ngawang Lhundrup, Jangngöné Kuzhönpa, Gyayak Gelong, the Chöpön, and the Umdzé. Bakdro has dreams with good omens.

event.note: Omens come to the Dalai Lama while he is doing practices.

socialEvent.note: The Dalai Lama composes a practice guide for Jamyang Drakpa and monks of Sera as well as a supplication prayer requested by Trinlé Samdrup.

There take place some activities relating to a reliquary stupa at Dzingchi (rdzing phyi) and an image of the deaceased Penjor Lhundrup (dpal 'byor lhun grub). The Dalai Lama writes a catalog (dkar chag) for the stupa once it has been consecrated.
Federica Venturi , Guide to the Rdzing phyi monastery. This book may have more information on Dzingchi and its monuments. UVa Library does not own a copy.
Zur Jamyang Lama requests [from the Dalai Lama] many teachings on new and old tantras.

event.note: There arises a large storm while the Dalai Lama is giving transmissions (rje gnang).

socialEvent.note: There is a request for an empowerment from the leaders of Drepung. However, there are complications. In response?, the Depa sends Mendrong Pelwa Tsewang Dargyé to Yarlung Tashi Tsé.
Confusing passage. It is unclear how the sending of Tsewang Dargye is a response to what I read as a debate over the appropriateness of a certain empowerment. (bjd 2009-04-07)
Dorjé Chang Kangyurwa Chenpo arrives. He requests several empowerments and teachings.
The Dalai Lama is sending Mondropa to Drepung to teach in his place. [Reading is tentative.]

Confusing passage. Begins with what seems to be personal reflections by the Dalai Lama, then goes on to what seems to be an exchange of letters and then sending Mondropa to Drepung. Also, is Mondropa P006, or maybe P147. Are these the same? (bjd 2009-04-07)
